#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Buy Mutual Funds for Children
#Text=Many parents want to invest money for their children 's futures that will earn good interest .
#Text=Mutual funds often earn a higher interest rate than certificates of deposit ( CD ) or other savings accounts , although they carry a slightly higher risk .
#Text=Mutual funds are an investment option where money is pooled from different investors in order to purchase securities .
#Text=A fund manager makes decisions as to how the money is invested .
#Text=A diversified mutual fund can be a good place to put money for a child 's college fund or nest egg .
#Text=Learn how to buy mutual funds for children .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Decide the reason you are investing the money .
#Text=For many parents , they are saving for college , but for others , it may be for travel , medical expenses or living expenses .
#Text=Calculate the amount of time you plan to invest the money before your child needs it .
#Text=If your child is very young and will not need the money for 20 years , you will want to choose different investments than if the child needs it in 5 years .
#Text=You may be able to choose a target-date mutual fund .
#Text=These investment vehicles allow you to name the year you will need the money .
#Text=Only a few dozen investment firms offer this , so you will have to look specifically for this type of mutual fund .
#Text=Consider other types of investments for children , as well as mutual funds .
#Text=Mutual funds often have attractive dividends ; however , other investments may have tax advantages .
#Text=If your child is college-bound , you may prefer a 529 college-savings plan .
#Text=The interest from these plans is not taxed by the IRS .
#Text=The options depend upon the state you live in , because some states allow you to choose a prepaid plan where you can buy tuition credits with today 's rates .
#Text=All states give a second option , the savings 529 plan .
#Text=These plans usually rely on mutual funds .
#Text=If your child is already working , they can start saving for retirement with a Roth IRA .
#Text=They can make contributions to the IRA depending upon the money they earn .
#Text=This money must be used for retirement if you want to get the tax benefits .
#Text=There are penalties for early withdrawal .
#Text=Set up a custodial account for your child .
#Text=Since a child cannot open an investment account on their own until they are 18 , you will need to open it with both your names on the account .
#Text=You may choose to do this at your own investment firm , in order to have ease of use and an investment broker you trust .
#Text=Choose an investment company and broker with a long track record .
#Text=This money may be in the mutual fund for a long period of time , so you should be sure that the company has a long term plan with excellent management .
#Text=Spend plenty of time researching investment companies in your area , and you may see the benefit with your own investments as well .
#Text=Look for mutual funds with low expenses .
#Text=Each investor in a mutual fund pays a fee to take part in the investment .
#Text=If these fees are large , they can add up over a long period of time , so compare using this metric as well as its past history .
#Text=Choose a highly-diversified mutual fund .
#Text=Diversified mutual funds carry less risk , because they put money in many different types of securities .
#Text=If 1 type of security falls , another is likely to compensate .
#Text=Choose mutual funds that do n't need to be watched constantly .
#Text=Diversified mutual funds are secure enough to allow a hands-off approach .
#Text=Talk with your broker about this aspect of different options .
#Text=Decide how much capital you will start with .
#Text=Gift a lump sum to your child for use with this initial investment .
#Text=Unless you have decided upon a Roth IRA , you can use this initial amount to start the investment and add money to it in other lump sums in the future .
#Text=Teach children about their mutual fund when they are old enough to understand .
#Text=By around age 10 , children can start being put in charge of their own savings accounts , with supervision .
#Text=The money site , The Mint , has an excellent article for younger readers on this topic .
#Text=View it at themint.org/kids/mutual-funds.html
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Investment broker
#Text=529 Plan
#Text=Roth IRA
#Text=Investment capital
#Text=Custodial account
#Text=Diversified mutual funds
#Text=Money management lessons
